DOC.HEAD: Brown of Houston Named Police Commissioner
LaserPhoto HT1
DOC.TEXT: Lee Brown, credited with easing racial tensions as Houston police chief, was named Monday as police commissioner for New York City, where he faces a drug-fueled crime wave. ``We need the best police commissioner we could find. Of all the finalists, he seemed to be the absolute best in the country,'' Mayor-elect David Dinkins said at a news conference to announce his choice to run America's biggest police force. Brown, chief in Houston since 1982 and one of four finalists for the New York job, takes over Jan. 22. He will head a department with 26,000 officers and 7,200 civilian employees, seven times larger than Houston's. ``I made a difficult decision, something I didn't feel I would be making when I was first talked to,'' Brown, 52, said at a news conference Monday in Houston. ``I talked about it and pondered, agonized and prayed.'' Brown was Houston's first black police chief, and has been credited for easing racial friction there. But Houston's force recently has been hit with allegations of racism and corruption, as well as controversy over shootings by officers. As New York's 36th police commissioner, Brown will face a city convulsed with drug-related crime. The murder rate is at a record level, and crack cocaine has been the main cause. ``The thing that will hit him immediately is the drug-crime problem,'' said Thomas Reppetto, head of the independent watchdog Citizens Crime Commission and a member of the search committee that interviewed Brown. Brown has said that each city's crime solutions are different, but he is a champion of community policing, with close cooperation between police and neighborhoods, Reppetto said. Before taking the Houston job, Brown was chief of public safety and chief of public safety for metropolitan Portland, Ore. He holds a doctorate in criminology from the University of California at Berkeley and is first vice president of the International Association of Chiefs of Police. Brown will become president of the association next year, said Reppetto. ``That's like an open door to the White House'' as an expert on police affairs, Reppetto said. Brown began his career as a policeman in San Jose, Calif., in 1960. He established Portland State University's criminal justice program eight years later and in 1972 joined Howard University, where he was associate director of the Institute for Urban Affairs and Research and director of the Criminal Justice Program. He went to Portland in 1975. Brown succeeds Commissioner Richard Condon, who took over Oct. 22 when longtime Commissioner Benjamin Ward retired. Ward was New York's first black police commissioner. Condon was one of the four finalists, and both Gov. Mario Cuomo and outgoing Mayor Edward I. Koch had urged Dinkins to keep Condon on. But Dinkins, who takes office Jan. 1, said he was swayed by the strong support Brown received from law enforcement experts.
